title: Can I become a freelance writer at age 17? - Quora

response.answer_text: Probably, but you will learn the hard way what customers do and don’t want. If it’s writing stuff for one outlet, like a news site, then you can slowly learn the ropes. But I don’t consider that freelancing - you’re just an employee with no benefits. True freelancing means having more than one client. To maintain that, you need to know how to handle your clients - and that’s experience you pick up best while working for someone else in an office. Alternatively, find a mentor who can guide you.

Yes. There is no age restriction for writers. In fact, if you have good writing skills, your age may be an advantage. All writer have a perspective. They are guided by their life experiences, beliefs, and values. Since most writers are older than you, you have the opportunity to introduce a fresh voice to your topic. I suggest you begin by taking inventory of any special knowledge you have. How can you leverage that knowledge into writing jobs? Are there publications, websites, blogs, or businesses that might benefit from your viewpoint? Do you have some writing samples you could share with potential clients? You are at a great age to start a freelance writing career. Just take action and get started! Jon Pennington | 11 Legit Places to Find Writing Jobs

Yes I am one. I work as a freelance content and copy writer on Upwork. You can check my profile out here. Age should not restrict you from doing anything (except its illegal). No one is too young or too old to become a writer.

Yes, surely! Just don’t expect any quick money. There is no short cut to get easy money. If you want to do it as a hobby, try a few free websites that offer freelancers a chance to post their work. I myself am looking forward to getting a decent income by freelance writing. Do your research and select a field you wish to become an expert in. Good luck!
You could if you are willing to be a life-long learner, reader, and willing to work hard and learn about the business side of freelancing.
